data.value: is a base class to construct specific distribution classes and instances for discrete random variables. It can also be used to construct an arbitrary distribution defined by a list of support points and corresponding probabilities.
. Whether a shape parameter is valid is decided by an
method (which defaults to checking that its arguments are strictly positive.) The main differences are:
the support of the distribution is a set of integers
instead of the probability density function,
To create a new discrete distribution, we would do the following:

>>> from scipy.stats import rv_discrete
>>> class poisson_gen(rv_discrete):
...     "Poisson distribution"
...     def _pmf(self, k, mu):
...         return exp(-mu) * mu**k / factorial(k)
Note that above we defined the Poisson distribution in the standard form. Shifting the distribution can be done by providing the
parameter to the methods of the instance. For example,

content.value: Discrete distributions from a list of probabilities

data.value: Alternatively, you can construct an arbitrary discrete rv defined on a finite set of values
Lower bound of the support of the distribution, default: 0
Upper bound of the support of the distribution, default: plus infinity
The tolerance for the generic calculation of moments.
are the non-zero probabilities between 0 and 1 with
Increment for the support of the distribution. Default is 1. (other values have not been tested)
The value in a result arrays that indicates a value that for which some argument restriction is violated, default is np.nan.
The name of the instance. This string is used to construct the default example for distributions.
This string is used as part of the first line of the docstring returned when a subclass has no docstring of its own. Note:
exists for backwards compatibility, do not use for new subclasses.

The shape of the distribution. For example "m, n" for a distribution that takes two integers as the two shape arguments for all its methods If not provided, shape parameters will be inferred from the signatures of the private methods,
This string is used as the last part of the docstring returned when a subclass has no docstring of its own. Note:
exists for backwards compatibility and will be removed in SciPy 1.11.0, do not use for new subclasses.
instance then that instance is used.
A generic discrete random variable class meant for subclassing.
